description: A substantivization of Low German güst (“dry and infertile”, adjective), from Middle Low German gēst (“dry, elevated”, literally “cracking, gaping, yawning”), from Old Saxon gīnan, from Proto-West Germanic *gīnan. See also German gähnen.

entries.meaning: A type of slightly raised landscape, with sandy and gravelly soils, that occurs in the plains of Northern Germany, the Northern Netherlands and Denmark.
examples: the waves, beating agaiņst the geest, were thence repelled upon the marsch.
